stories.text:
This is the first thing I've made in a while - it's a simple service that lets you make a neat little blog.

You can add custom HTML/JS/CSS, posts can be formatted with markdown, and every site gets an RSS feed. It also has server-rendered social card images, and once a post is published, you can see basic stats about how it's doing.

You can try it out for free, and then once you're ready to make your site public, it's just a $20 one-time payment to keep the lights on.

Let me know what you think :)
stories.title: Show HN: Write.cx – a neat little blogging site I've made
Adverse effects of Covid-19 vaccines and measures to prevent them
Carbon Language – First Impressions from the Creator of Odin [video]
You can adopt a Python called JavaScript from Budapest zoo
UK heatwave crashed cooling systems for Google and Oracle cloud servers
How the Ukraine war could make New Englanders shiver
JavaScript AST manipulation with Babel: the first steps

stories.text:
Given the reversal of Roe V Wade, we've seen a great deal of doctor-ordered drugs refused to be vended by pharmacists due to "religious reasons". A variety of these drugs treat symptoms like lupus, Crohn's, and others. They do share a side-effect, in that they can cause a spontaneous abortion.

Combined with that, are places like CVS that put out an order to all pharmacists to withhold these drugs. https://newrepublic.com/article/167087/roe-cvs-methotrexate-abortion-pills

So I'm asking this: what is the feasibility of automating a pharmacy, to make faster, cheaper, and less biased service for what your doctor orders? Have any YC companies approached this?

(Please note: this is a feasibility of automating pharmacies. I do not wish this to be yet another tired pro/anti abortion thread. We have enough of those online. And those never provide answers - only more angry people.)
stories.title: Ask HN: What is the feasibility of completely automating a pharmacy?
